Biden is betwern a rock and a hard place in choosing a vp who would keep the more liberal crowd to still go out to vote for him (instead of choosing a third party that is more progressive), while also trying to persuade more of the evangelical sect to vote for Biden instead of Trump. Kamala Harris has the name recognition and the experience to be selected as VP, but she may turn off Middle America, especially the evangelical vote. I think strategically for Biden, he already won the votes of people who claim anybody (you know, any functional adult) is better than Trump. So maybe Harris isn't the best, but she is a woman of color, and that does give her some more value as a vp contender. It is crazy to me to talk of race as something of value to Biden, but we live in a world that minorities (I am a minority) want to be represented in one of the highest offices in the country (and I will be glad when that happens). We also live in a country where Christianity is basically a cornerstone, so those values need to be there, somehow exemplified in a vp candidate. Trump is going to play the card that Biden is not Christian, even though he is Catholic (and many Christians falsely see Catholics as not Christian til this day). Really, hate formulating this forecasr based on demographics but a majority of American votes seem to be persuaded more on race and religious values than merit.

I have spent the last week trying to reconcile my historical analysis of VP picks with the current field of contenders and I just don’t think that my original thesis fits. After some introspection, I feel that my forecast was influenced by response bias. The list of candidates led me to conclude that I had to assign a non-zero probability to each pick, therefore coming up with approaching the question in a way that facilitated such an answer. That’s not to say the research that I did was completely useless as it was a good exercise in contrarian thinking. That being said, there is a growing consensus as we enter the first week of August that the most likely victors in the contest are either Sen. Kamala Harris or former National Security Advisor Susan Rice. I won’t spend much time rationalizing Harris as a pick except to say that she would not contradict my earlier analysis. She may not be the top pick according to my model but nobody would be considering we are choosing from an all-female, mostly black field, that really precludes the kind of profile that modern VPs tend to have.

If you trust the reporting, which is hard on a subject like this because sources can be either clueless donors or campaign officials purposefully leaking or floating things to the press to see how they play, then it is clear that Karen Bass and Susan Rice are contenders https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/01/us/politics/trump-biden-polls-vp.html

I could well be wrong, I think this is very difficult to predict, but I have to put what I think even though I'm strongly contradicting the crowd here.

Kamala Harris is an African American woman with name recognition, powerful debate skills, and a similar policy beliefs and backgrounds as Biden. Warren is also a woman and has a lot of name recognition and proved herself on the debate stage, but she appeals more to progressives, who will most likely support Biden anyways. With racial tensions being what they are, a toss-up skews heavily towards Harris. Stacey Abrams has done everything she can to lobby for the role and gained national attention for her initiatives in Georgia, but is rarely seen as a real contender for the VP position. The rest only become viable if Biden seeks to surprise the electorate, which seems unlikely given his platforms and general appeal to a return to normalcy.

I don’t think there is anyone in Washington or even the entire United States who doesn’t believe this is an unprecedented and unorthodox question to be answering this late in the campaign. The conventional wisdom is that a presidential hopeful chooses his running mate before the general election race begins. Then again, conventional wisdom would also limit one to picking a man as his vice president and that is clearly not the situation we are in now. Despite this being such an unusual point in election history, where a nominee for president has publicly committed himself to choose and a woman and probably an African American one to fill the VP spot, I think many of the standard political considerations still hold true. And those assumptions are what I am going to use to establish my base rates. Let’s talk geography.This is how the 14 post WWII Vice Presidents break down. I’m using regional designations from the US Census Bureau to standardize things. [1][2] 6 out of 14 - South (43%)
6 out of 14 - Midwest (43%)
1 of of 14 - Northeast (7%)
1 of of 14 - West (7%) As we can see it is ‘almost certain’ on the Sherman Kent scale (88%) that the Vice President will either be from the Midwest or the South. This makes sense electorally speaking. Both regions are home to key states like Michigan, Ohio, Florida and Texas. If you want to win the White House you have to have a good showing here. But it doesn’t take long to notice that black, southern women are disproportionately underweighted in my prediction. That’s because location isn’t the only thing that matters when picking a VP - experience is a huge factor. Look at this break down of second-in-commands by previous experience [3]: 1 out of 14 - Cabinet Secretary (7%)
2 out of 14 - Only House of Representatives (14%)
2 out of 14 - Ambassador (14%)
2 out of 14 - Mayor (14%)
3 out of 14 - Legal (21%)
3 out of 14 - Governor (21%)
7 out of 14 - Senate (50%) Clearly Senate experience is a huge factor - doubly important when compared to the next closest. Perhaps even more so because the other categories - except House only - are skewed by crosstabs. That’s why Senators Klobuchar (Michigan) and Baldwin (Wisconsin) score so highly compared to the rest of the field. They have Senate experience and come from statistically important states.  By contrast those with only limited government experience like Abrams and Demmings fall well behind the rest of the pack. Governor Whitman comes from an important state but being a governor is much less favored in vetting combined with the fact that she was only recently elected. The same goes for Governor Grisham in New Mexico who has some House experience but currently serves as head of a state which ranks near bottom in electoral prestige. Worthy of mention too, are Democratic stars Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren who, although serving in the Senate, represent states on the margins of the vice presidential scrum. States which are also solidly blue, minimize the benefit (vote-winning at least) of choosing either as a running mate. This is just an initial forecast and there is plenty of news flying around that could change the picture completely day-to-day. Here’s a great link I’ll be using to stay up-to-date with this question: https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/27/joe-biden-vp-running-mate-pick-tracker-377652 Comments welcome. [1]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_vice_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_place_of_primary_affiliation
[2]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_regions_of_the_United_States#/media/File:Census_Regions_and_Division_of_the_United_States.svg
[3]https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_vice_presidents_of_the_United_States_by_other_offices_held

VP Predictions Joe Biden’s campaign has been clear that his vice presidential pick will be a woman. The US has never had a female president or VP, and Democrats (and the country at large) are intent on changing that, and breaking the proverbial glass ceiling. At this point, the campaign and betting markets have explicitly ruled out the possibility of a male VP pick, for this reason, I have priced that probability at 0%.  Joe Biden is a particularly interesting party nominee. He is a centrist Democrat, career politician and comes from a working class background. He famously claims that he was the first senator he met. Biden is also older for a nominee at 78 years old. It is widely suspected he will be a one term president if he wins in November. This has important implications for his vice-presidential pick. If Joe Biden wins in November, which is likely (70%), his VP will be the favorite running as a near incumbent. In short, Joe Biden’s campaign’s team has been tasked with choosing the new leader of the Democratic Party.  Recent events have highlighted the injustices that Black Americans in the United States experience, and again elevated the discussion of race relations to the front of the national conscious. Spurred by incidents of police brutality, the past two months have again brought to light the disparity between the lives of white and black Americans. Police brutality against black Americans is nothing new. However, since the 2012 shooting of Trayvon Martin, the US as a whole has changed its opinions of the black lives matter movement. Americans of all races are significantly more likely to support recent protests than they were five years ago. Sporting organizations have changed course on their approach to protest by players before games. The country is more ready and willing to examine the ways in which black Americans are systemically oppressed. Because of this, I believe it would be politically deft of Joe Biden to chose a black women as his VP pick - and betting markets agree. Joe Biden needs to think of the implications of his pick. He is the favorite in the polls, and has polling leads in swing states. He needs a safe play: an uncontroversial pick. Donald Trump will continue to mismanage the Coronavirus epidemic, and the election is only four months away. Joe Biden’s dominant strategy would be to make uncontroversial moves, and to chose an experienced politician, who the public is widely familiar with. These are three criteria on which I believe the campaign (which has likely already made their decision) should consider, is the VP pick: a suitable Democratic Party leader for 2024 (“prediential”), a politically expedient choice for the current times and safe. The front runner of betting markets is current Kamala Harris, a California senator. However, she has one weakness, which is that she was a prosecutor as the AG of California. She is undoubtably presidential and would be a safe pick for the VP role with Biden. She also has the greatest brand recognition as a former candidate for the nomination, but hails from California, the opposite of a swing state. Betting markets price her odds at 40%. I think this is bearish. There is nothing wrong with Kamala Harris. She was a near front runner for the election about 9 months ago, and performed particularly well in the debates. Had her campaign not but horrifically mismanaged their budget, she would’ve been one of final holdouts. Nationally, she has good favorability ratings. She’s a great speaker and debater, and would be strong against Mike Pence in the VP debate this fall. I think the next most likely choice is Susan Rice. I personally believe she would be the best choice for the democrats. She was Obama’s ambassador to the UN and National Security Advisor. She has strengths in foreign policy, is ideologically a centrist and is undoubtably uncontroversial. However, the blame of the Benghazi attack in 2012 has been somewhat cast upon her, and she has never held elected office. There are more unknowns with Rice than with Harris, and she has less brand recognition. I think betting markets are correct that she has about a 28% chance of winning. Betting markets think Elizabeth Warren is another possible choice. I fundamentally disagree with this. I think Elizabeth Warren is an unlikely (though not impossible) choice. She is a Penn and Harvard professor turned MA senator. She’s a brilliant orator and was nearly solely responsible for knocking Michael Bloomberg out of the Democratic race by eviscerating him in two debates. Like Harris, she would likely outperform Pence at the VP debate this fall. However, she is ideologically concerning as a Biden pick. A social democrat at heart, Warren has highly liberal aspirations that are not particularly popular nationally, but more importantly are polarizing - the opposite of what Biden’s campaign needs. For what it’s worth, she also has a minor racial controversy in her past. She also only endorsed Joe Biden after Bernie Sanders. Warren fans believe that she would be a unifying choice for the party. Donald Trump is the ultimate unifying force for Democrats- Biden has other areas he should focus on. I think she is outmatched on many important metrics by Harris and Rice, and despite being the most politically experienced, is an unlikely choice.  Keisha Lance Bottoms, the mayor of Atlanta is another name that has been mentioned in the past two months. She has never held national (or state level) office. Atlanta hasn’t done a great job handling the coronavirus pandemic. I think this would be an unwise choice. She has been in the news a lot the past two months which is good for name recognition, as she has dealt with Atlanta protests and the coronavirus pandemic, with mixed results. However, this would be a surprising choice given how important the VP pick will be in 2024 as a Democratic Party leader. Stacy Abrams is another possible choice. She is a brilliant Yale Law choice who nearly won the Georgia governorship in 2018. She has never held national or state-leave office. She is a rising Democratic star, but choosing someone young and politically inexperienced to become the de-facto leader of the Democratic Party in 2024 seems unwise. I do not think she will be the VP choice as in recent weeks she’s declined to say if she is still in the running for the role. I price her likelihood at 1%. Tammy Duckworth is another possible choice. She is a senator from Illinois. She is a veteran and a Purple Heart recipient. I think her recent bump in betting markets is due to being in a clash with Tucker Carlson two weeks ago.  She would potentially be good for appealing to veterans. I think the bettings markets view of 12% is bullish, and 9% or 75% of that value is more in line. I do not believe Gretchen Whitmer has a chance at being chosen as VP. The same goes for Klobutchar. Both are outmatched on too many metrics by the above candidates. PredictIt lists the current odds for the candidates as follows, which provides a good base rate.
Harris 38%
Rice 27%
Duckworth 12%
Warren 8%
Demings 9% I think that the markets are undervaluing Harris and Rice, which as mentioned I see as the only two sensible choices. I think Joe Biden, a career politician with a deeply experienced team will not chose Bottoms or Abrams, though I think Abrams is more likely. Using a simple model I wrote, I think the market has underweighted Harris and Rice’s odds by about 25%, but has the relative likelihood correct.  Finally, sometimes crazy things happen in politics. In 2008, John McCain, the definition of a career politician, who was running against a young, inexperienced Democrat selected Sarah Palin. The move was shocking and resulted in his downfall. The memory of an inexperienced VP pick remains fresh in the minds of the political establishments.

Change: Duckworth (-6), Harris (+13), Another Woman (+7), Klobuchar (-10), Whitmer (-1). Warren (-3).  Reasoning: TLDR changes in reporting on who is on the shorter list and response to the Floyd protests (https://www.boston.com/news/politics/2020/06/14/biden-running-mate-search-black-women-elizabeth-warren).  This forum has responded quite strongly to the Floyd protests. I now see the crowd forecast with Harris at 57%, Another Woman at 31% and Warren, Amy, and Whitmer dropped to zero. Comparing with Predicit (https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5883/Who-will-win-the-2020-Democratic-vice-presidential-nomination) suggests that these dramatic shifts are an overreaction, and I think driven by the news cycle. I will comment on the "overrated" candidates in a second but for now, I am going to the "underrated" candidates: Klobuchar and Duckworth. While Amy has seen quite a fall, I don't think 0 is appropriate, she is still one of the few candidates who match Biden's fundamentals and even James Clayburn, Biden confidant, and congressional BC member, wouldn't rule her out (https://www.boston.com/news/politics/2020/06/14/biden-running-mate-search-black-women-elizabeth-warren). Duckworth also remains strong on the fundamentals. Still, I have to acknowledge that the changing conversation will likely change Bidens thinking: hence the dramatic fall. (Also cause I haven't updated in a while).  Warren is being criminally underrated. I have her in the same range as always because I still see no reason why her stock should fall. Particularly given her favorability amongst young African Americans compared to other candidates (https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/election/article243566952.html). 
Now to the overrated candidates. My theory in this question is that most news articles speculating who the VP is to be are often more about the reporter's opinion than the opinions of people advising Biden, let alone Biden himself. Often people in the extended circle of Biden donors gossip and formulate their own opinions (donors often play at being powerful and smart) which then get carried by the news. Except those opinions are themselves driven by how they see the campaign and the news cycle. To reiterate: they do not actually possess information about how Biden views the VP pick.  As a result, I think that Demmings and Bottoms are being very overrated right now. They have had an outsized presence in the media and that has led to speculation. But they are very far off the mark when it comes to the kind of candidate Biden wants: a national profile with DC experience. Hence why I have "Another woman" 15 points below the crowd. Of the candidates in this category that I think are realistic I would say Susan Rice sticks out the most, particularly because she worked with Biden in his administration and is an old hand in DC. Tho her national profile is wanting. Harris' stock naturally rises as the field narrows and as her competition looks worse and worse. I would say she is a little overrated, I would probably put her close to 48% myself, but I think she is definitely the front runner so I am adjusting to the crowd.

Change: Duckworth (+3), Harris (-1), Warren (-2) Reasoning: Did some research on Duckworth today in, partly prompted by Biden's comments making me think he's thinking strongly about non-African American candidates. Fun facts: Duckworth's entire political career she has been pushed along by Dick Durbin, the senior Senator from Illinois who recruited her for her first run at the congress. When that race didn't go well Obama got her a job in the VA until the next cycle in 2012. In 2016 her Senate race was one of the only ones to get the Biden-Obama endorsement and personal appearance. Part of all of this is that she has Obama's old senate seat.  In other words, Duckworth is one of the few candidates who has a history of being in the Obama-Biden orbit. She particularly contrasts with Klobuchar who does not have as much of personal history, at least not one that I have been able to find, as a moderate that more fits Joe Biden's politics. Illinois is also the mid-west but I don't think the Biden campaign cares about that logic. Given the ambiguity of who Biden has chemistry with, I think Duckworth is a strong 4th place.  My priors on Warren put her between 20-25 and on Harris put her between 40-55 so I'm comfortable dropping both of them. If Duckworth appears at an event with Biden, which many of the other candidates have, I will probably jump her to 6% to the expense of Amy and Another.

Change: Harris (-4), Warren (+2), Klobuchar (+2) Reasoning: A new piece on Warren's chances (https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/05/elizabeth-warren-biden-vice-president/611497/), with the following data points: 1) Warren and Obama have been chatting frequently and there is serious consideration of her in his circle. 2) She has been tuning her message to quash feelings that she is not a "team player" which is necessary because there remains some discomfort about how much she would be "simpatico" and serve Biden's agenda if chosen. 3) Further confirmation that Biden really wants to pick someone who ran for president to serve as his VP. The most likely option is a woman whom no one has thought of in the zeitgeist. I'm basing that on the fact that there are hundreds, if not over a thousand, female politicians who may meet the criteria for a VP. This is especially poignant when adds to the list prominent republican women, such as Jenean Hampton of Kentucky, who would represent a unity ticket with the explicit goal of beating the incumbent. If Hampton didn't have close ties to the Tea Party, I'd say either her or someone in a similar position were the most likely candidate. Of those who are commonly spoken about, I give Tammy Duckworth the highest odds at 20%. She would check a lot of boxes for a lot constituencies the Biden campaign likely wants to placate. She is from a Midwestern state with a Democratic governor who would appoint a democrat to her seat should she become the VP.  She's generally progressive but not to a point where she would become a political liability any more so than Joe Biden himself already is. Stacey Abrams comes in at 16% because she would similarly check a lot of boxes, particularly with the black voters who have propelled Biden to the nomination. The only reason her and Duckworth don't have equal odds is her general lack of experience in elected office. My guess is that the Biden campaign, regardless of who the pick, is assuming that the VP has higher probability of actually becoming president due to Biden's age when entering office. As a result, they are in all likelihood prioritizing government experience over many other factors. Which leads to Gretchen Whitmer at 15%. Whitmer would be a solid pick because of her executive experience however, the fact that she is white and that there was a large amount of dialogue about the primary eventually narrowing down to an effectively all white field works against her potential as a VP pick. On top of that, Michigan has faded from blue to purple over the last election cycles and with the difficult policy decisions related COVID-19 she will have to make, it's likely that Whitmer's favorability will begin to decline in the coming months. Next up we have Biden's former primary opponents. I find it unlikely he will pick a VP from the list of other presidential candidates during the 2020 cycle. Amy Klobochar has better odds than Harris or Warren because she at least did not openly attack Biden in ways that received lots of coverage. She was also not at any point a front runner in the campaign. On top of that, Warren and Harris would both highlight the inconsistent speech patterns of Biden and the last thing the Biden campaign wants is to make their candidate look weak. All that said, i think there is a non-negligible possibility that the Biden campaign picks someone who is not a woman, particularly when one considers that broad range of viable options who are also people of color. I understand Biden made that promise but it would not shock me if they reneged on that promise.

The Criteria Joe Biden has set out for his Vice President is -
Must be a Woman, Younger, In sync with his Political Positions and Able to be President.
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/16/us/politics/joe-biden-vp-running-mate.html With regard to Criteria 1, will assume he will stick by it with so Not a Woman = 0%.
This leaves the following possible Candidates - Amy Klobuchar, Tammy Duckworth, Kamala Harris, Gretchen Whitmer, Stacey Abrams, Elizabeth Warren and Another Woman. In assigning the probability of each Candidate I will adopt a filter system of multiple layers with Candidates compared against each layer and removed if necessary. The layers are - I Age, II Politics, III Experience, IV Replaceable & Eligibility, V Do no Harm I Age - This layer relates to Criteria 2, which I will assume means the VP must be at least 10 years younger than Biden who is 77 years old. Of the 6 Candidates, only Elizabeth Warren fails to meet this Criteria at age 70 years old, Elizabeth Warren = 0% II Politics -This layer deals with Criteria 3, meaning that the VP must share his Political Ideology. Biden is a Moderate Democrat- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Democrats
Aside from Elizabeth Warren (Progressive), all the 5 Candidates appear to be of the same Political Ideology (more or less) as Biden. III Experience -This relates to a Candidate's length of Experience of Governing in National Office (e.g. US Congress, State Governor, Executive Branch etc) and addresses Criteria 4. In reviewing the most recent 16 Vice Presidential Nominations from 1976 - 2016 I found the length of Experience VP's had of Governing in National Office upon being nominated were -
1 - 6 Years = 3/16 = 19% (Edwards 2004, Ferraro 1984, Palin 2008)
7 - 12 Years = 5/16 = 31% (Kaine 2016, Lieberman 2000, Mondale 1976, Bush 1980, Quayle 1988)
x>=13 Years = 8/16 = 50% (Pence 2016, Ryan 2012, Cheney 2000, Kemp 1996, Bentsen 1988, Biden 2008, Gore 1992, Dole 1976) This agrees with my research of the Vice Presidency in how it has grown in recent decades into a Governing Partnership with the President with a VP with lots of Experience in National Office highly desirable.
Given Stacey Abrams has no Experience in National Office, I believe she has no chance of being selected VP, Stacey Abrams = 0%. All the previous 16 VP candidates had at least some National Office Experience with Sarah Palin the shortest at 1 year as Alaskan Governor. Using the code A = 19% = 1 - 6 Years, B = 31% = 7 - 12 Years, C = 50% = x>=13 Years, I will code the Candidates based on their Experience of National Office - 
(13 Years) Klobuchar = C = 50% = 41%
(3 Years) Harris = A = 19% = 16%
(11 Years) Duckworth = B = 31% = 27%
(1 Year) Whitmer = A = 19% = 16% I debated whether being a State Attorney General like Kamala Harris is Governing Experience but I decided against it. Of the 16 VP nominees, 2 have been a State Attorney General (Mondale / Lieberman) but both already had strong experience in the Senate (12 / 11 Years) upon being selected. IV Replaceable & Eligibility, Replaceable refers to if that Person is chosen as Vice President. How will the Vacancy they create be filled ?
To the best of my Research, neither Klobuchar, Harris, Duckworth or Whitmer present any significant challenges like Warren (Republican Governor fills her Senate Seat) if they create a Vacancy. 
To be eligible for the Vice Presidency, must be Natural Born US Citizen, Minimum 35 Years Old and Lived in the USA for the Last 14 Years. An issue for Duckworth (Like Ted Cruz in 2016) is she was born outside the USA (Thailand) with one of her parents an US Citizen. The Supreme Court has yet to rule if Natural Born means being born in the USA or not - https://www.politifact.com/article/2015/mar/26/ted-cruz-born-canada-eligible-run-president-update/ V Do No Harm - An consensus of VP's is they shouldn't be perceived to hurt a Presidential chances (For Example Palin 2008, Ferraro 1984, Eagleton 1972).

First, politicians tend to keep their promises about 75% (https://www.vox.com/2015/11/27/9801800/politicians-keep-campaign-promises) of the time and that is across all the exigencies of their political life. Biden promised to select a woman. He has full control over this decision and it is hard to see events unfold that would render that a bad choice. So I think there is less than 5% chance he selects a man. Second, over the last 40 years, over 80% of VP picks of a major party are politicians with national standing (VP, Senator, cabinet member) and politicians are aware that having national experience is important to running (Obama once doubted whether Palin had enough time to become a national Candidate because it took him "4 months" to learn how to do it). This causes me to downgrade Stacey Abrams significantly. Third, there are two voting blocks I think Biden needs: 1) African Americans (which Kamala Harris would help); 2) Bernie voters (which Warren would help). Warren was the main second choice for Bernie voters, albeit, with only 30% of them. Biden already is a popular candidate with African American voters. Winning 75+% support in final primaries. That said, he was also a popular second choice for Bernie voters. Fourth, I do note that the average age difference for P/VP is greater than 10 years. And of the 30% of the time the age difference is less than that, 90% of those scenarios the candidates were young (<56 years old). So I greatly discount Warren. Revising my previous: I think that Biden will have Obama campaigning for him which helps on the African American front, but he will desperately need Midwestern voters. Which means I should bump Klobuchar much higher.

The world is speeding fast. I think there will be considerable pressure on Biden to pick a running mate that is both a woman and a minority group, so I suspect of the known names, Stacey Abrams or Kamala Harris are the only very likely candidates. I think, though, that it is more likely that Joe Biden will pick someone who is not one of the known names. As the world is changing so fast and we're getting new heroes all the time, it's even possible that he might pick a man.

Biden said he's picking a woman, so it's going to be a woman. 
Stacy Abrams would probably fit in on a Biden team well enough, but against the other women candidates the next biggest box she checks off is the appeal to black voters. Biden does well with that demographic already, owing to 8 years working side-by-side with President Obama, who will be leaving the sidelines to endorse him very soon, so the added value to the ticket maybe isn't there. 
Likewise, Duckworth is a veteran, and that never hurts, but her home state of Illinois, where she's best known, is not a going concern for the Biden campaign. 
Warren might be the best prepared to be a useful contributor to a future Biden administration, and if that were to occur she may find herself headed for a cabinet-level position, but she is still just too liberal to be on this ticket, which will inevitably be designed to appeal more broadly across the middle of the ideological spectrum. Of all the former Democratic presidential candidates, Warren was the most feared by Wall street, and the Biden campaign can't afford to lose any Big-money liberal support.
Kamala Harris is bringing money to the table herself, with fundraising help and there's lots of money to be raised in her home state of California. But if she's the VP, then she can't be Biden's AG, and with her background as AG of California, that is ultimately probably her best fit in a Biden administration.
That leaves Klobuchar and Whitmer. Both bring their popularity in a vital battleground  to the table. Minnesota (narrowly won by Clinton in '16) for Klobuchar, and Michigan (narrowly won by Trump in '16) for Whitmer. Klobuchar would be the more traditional pick here, but Whitmer's status has been greatly elevated by her management and actions during the Covid-19 illness crisis occurring in her state and for her willingness to go toe-to-toe with Trump when it came to fighting for her state. Whitmer is still a lesser known quantity on the national stage, but her surging popularity in Michigan could move that state into much more of a sure thing for the Democratic ticket in the fall.
Harris made a deal with the DNC to raise money for them. Haven't heard of other deals made yet with anyone else.

The highest chance for the Biden VP choice is an African American woman.  Biden owes his rapid change of fortune against Sanders to the black voters, as demonstrated by the endorsement of Clyburn and their overwhelming support in South Carolina.  I give 75% chance that the VP choice is an African-American woman. Warren, being white and on the left wing part of the Democratic party, has very low chance. Whitmer (Michigan) and Klobuchar (Minnesota) are both white and from the Midwest.  Choosing them will base on their ability to win the electoral votes in their state.  Minnesota has 10 votes and it is leaning Dem.  Michigan is a tossup and it has 16 votes.  On this account, Whitmer has better odds than Klobuchar.  However, Klobuchar has generated lots of exposure running for the presidential nomination.  I give them equal odds. Duckworth is Thai-American and a disabled veteran from Illinois.  Illinois is solidly Democratic.  She also has a low profile.  I think she is unlikely to be chosen. This leaves Harris and Abrams, both African Americans, and an yet unknown African American woman. Abrams has a lesser resume than Harris although she did very well in her running for the Georgia governor, losing by 50,000 votes. In her speech ending her campaign, she announced the creation of Fair Fight Action, a voting rights nonprofit organization that sued the Secretary of State and state election board in federal court for voter suppression. The lawsuit was still ongoing [1].  While she has the potential to deliver Georgia to the Dem, her ongoing lawsuit might be a distraction for the presidential campaign.   Harris ran for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination.  She has an impressive resume, being the AG and Senator from California.  She is very articulate.  Her disadvantage is that California is solidly Dem.  However, I give Harris higher odds than Abrams. 

[1]  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stacey_Abrams#2018_gubernatorial_campaign
Clyburn's choice and other reasons; smart black woman, tough, good debater, Senate seat not up in 2020. Can take on Trump better than Biden but that part may not help Biden.

Biden has said that he will name a woman as his VP....I think that he will make good on this promise.  Kamala Harris broadens Biden's ticket demographically in terms of ethnicity and race.  She is a moderate but more liberal than Biden so potentially widens Biden's appeal to progressives. She also doesn't hurt the Democratic senate percentage, she is from CA where democratic governor Newsom will name her replacement. Doesn't hurt Biden's ticket. Amy Klobuchar is another great pick...a moderate, however I feel that she doubles down on Biden's midwest and working class appeal. She is a bit more progressive but doesn't significantly differ from Biden's ideology so doesn't offer much in widening Biden's ideologic appeal. She also lacks the ability to broaden Biden's appeal with minorities.   Elizabeth Warren is a progressive favorite however I feel that she would be a detractor to a Biden ticket and turn off many moderates so this would hurt the ticket. She may appeal to the party elite however this group is already a part of the Biden coalition. She is from MA where her replacement would be chosen in a special election in 2021 which might possibly result in losing a senate seat. She doesn't broaden Biden's appeal to minorities so I feel that she takes more away from the ticket than she brings to the ticket. Stacy Abrams....might broaden Biden's appeal ideologically and with minorities however she lacks experience in bigger government and I believe her outspokenness during the GA gubernatorial race was polarizing and exactly the divisive politics that is destroying this country.
